summary: Built on seven hills where the Tagus River meets the Atlantic, Lisbon enchants visitors with its white-limestone buildings, intimate alleyways, cafe culture and historic charm.
Former imperial capital (794-1868) spared from WWII bombings; today one of Japan’s largest cities known for thousands of temples, shrines and preserved heritage.
Capital of Egypt and one of Africa’s largest cities; located on the Nile’s eastern bank with monuments from the Pyramids of Giza to bustling bazaars.
Oldest and highest U.S. state capital; a cultural hub mixing Pueblo, Hispanic and modern influences with art galleries, museums, a historic plaza and adobe architecture.
Legislative capital and South Africa’s oldest city; known for its harbour and landmarks like Table Mountain and Cape Point, and for being a port-city cultural hub.
Founded 1070-72 by the Almoravids; a political, economic and cultural centre with monuments like the Koutoubia Mosque and UNESCO-listed medina.
Town inside Banff National Park at high elevation; famous for skiing and outdoor activities amid mountains, glaciers, lakes and hot springs.
Megacity of over ten million; capital and economic, political and cultural centre of South Korea with palaces, museums and a mix of historic sites and modern skyscrapers.
Capital of Tuscany; cradle of the Renaissance and a UNESCO-listed city renowned for medieval trade heritage, art and architecture.
Adventure Capital on Lake Wakatipu; glacial basin ringed by dramatic ranges offering over 200 adventure activities.
Capital and largest city of Argentina on the Rio de la Plata; major port and centre of arts and education.
Pink City; capital of Rajasthan founded in 1727 and UNESCO World Heritage site with treasures like Hawa Mahal and Amber Fort.
Capital and largest city of Iceland on the Seltjarnar Peninsula; the world’s northernmost sovereign capital, now a modern geothermal-heated cultural hub.
